instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Hi guys i have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that not boot... (stuck at 5v)

here there is the history of previous techician (i can't say if it is 100% true)

macbook dead

found a short with thermal camera on <CAPACITOR>C3000</CAPACITOR>

caps removed (not replaced)

tried to charge -> smoke

found <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> burnt

changed, no luck

changed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> no luck

rechanged <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with the original one. No luck

now i have this laptop.



i have changed both usb-c chip from a IDENTICAL donor board and <CAPACITOR>C3000</CAPACITOR>

FINALLY 20V! BUT NO BOOT

Using Thermal camera i have <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> super hot

[URL unfurl="true"]https://uploadnow.io/it/share?utm_medium=46288f1b-0bf1-4d76-9980-eeb33a19aa0d[/URL]


I have checked for shorts around and under <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> with no luck



I have pp3v3 ldo 3v
I have ppbus pmic 13v
I have <SIGNAL>PP1V25_REF</SIGNAL> 1,3v

But pp5v ldo stuck at 2,7v This Line is not shorted


replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (from donor board)

Now i have po5vldo… <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is not super hot anymore…(but hot together with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>)

Now is super hot <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and a little bit cpu…

This is the amp meter

[URL]https://uploadnow.io/f/nJDYmsx[/URL]

Changed <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> still the same

I have Nothing on display, no caps lock no fan spinning

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Check if the redriver chip is not also burnt.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1cufCRucKvdO4RLoyMMmHvDNDpP8NebtR/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

Check diode mode to ground on all big coils and other test points.
Compare with good board, or reference table.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://openboarddata.org/?a=showboardsolutions&bpath=laptops/apple/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/URL]

After all, CPU may be dead; be aware of that.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
thank you for your reply!

redriver chip seems perfect

yes i have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> stable

checked big coils with this awesome table chart you gave me...seems all ok

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
First, be sure <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> stays normally high at 3V.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message: Then, check for pulse (0->3V) at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message: Yes i have the pulse

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
You should have pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> too; confirm that.
Then check for pulse at all big coils; when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
You can use SW9988/89 pads, instead of power button; solder <RESISTOR>R9988</RESISTOR>, if not in place.

Test if machine turns on in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  goes to 3,3 as soon as i connect power suppply, then come back to 0 after some seconds then to 3,3 (stable)

<RESISTOR>R9988</RESISTOR> is not in place...should i do a jumper with a wire? is the jumper for "bypass mode"?



ps you ask me to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

then you said that i can use sw9988..but it is <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> _R : is it the same?

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Not the same, if <RESISTOR>R9988</RESISTOR> is not soldered.
Mentioned pads are bigger and more easy to use; but imply soldering <RESISTOR>R9988</RESISTOR>.
However, if you feel comfortable, just use an wire soldered to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>.

If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> remains high, then you should have voltage on all big coils; maybe not on CPU coils.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>   goes to 3,3 as soon as i connect power suppply, then come back to 0 after some seconds then to 3,3

but this behavious is WITHOUT trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

if i try to short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> nothing happen!

i have no voltage on the 3 big coils on the left of the cpu

I have <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and ssd super hot (47 degrees), then <CHIP>U5800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> hot

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Power on sequence starts when charger is connected.
I said to test triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, because you didn't mention to have voltage on any big coil; apart of <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

L7410/20/30 will not get voltage as normal; nor even when board boots.
What voltage do you get on L7210/20, after 10s?
If nothing, check L7370 voltage too.

BTW, when you deal with groups of 2-3 coils, good enough to check one coil only.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message: No voltage in All Coil you ask me to check

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Now check L7730, L7900/60 and L8030/60.
Also check all output voltages from page 64 (Power FETs).

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Probably CPU problem then.

Just in case, try known good BIOS.
Also check all BootROM SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Did you also check the traces of BootROM resistors?
Tried the BIOS?

This board can boot without <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> stays high?
Check <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltages; pins 41, 42, 48.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
"pin 42 0v"
Check diode mode to ground there.
If short, bad <CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR>, or <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Anyway, <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR> is burnt/open.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
In diode mode i have 0.001mv

in ohm mode i have 2. ohm to ground

replaced <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR>, but no luck, still 0v on pin 42

removing <CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR>, i have still 1,2ohm resistence


replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> now i have 2v on pin 42

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Replace again <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR>; it got burnt because of bad <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
I never said to replace <RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR> BEFORE finding the cause of short.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Do you have 5V at pin1/<RESISTOR>R7192</RESISTOR>?
If yes, same voltage must be found on pin2; is just 1 ohm resistor (if not burnt).

threads.message:

Also check for USB activity.
If not, try known good BIOS, clean ME.

threads.title: [help] FIRST POST: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> DEAD AND HOT AS HELL
threads.message:
Check first if you get 5V at pin 46/J8500.
Resolder original <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>; be sure to get good solders.

Keyboard can't work if trackpad is bad...
